explanation:
The report is not correct. Rule 2.2 forbids operations whose removal would not affect program behaviour. An assertion (LFS_ASSERT -> assert) is not merely a redundant read: when enabled it is an executed runtime check that can change program behaviour (typically by aborting) if the invariant is violated. Therefore the assertion is not guaranteed to be removable without affecting behaviour, and so generally does not qualify as dead code under MISRA 2.2. 

While the assertion compiles away when NDEBUG is defined, that fact alone does not make the source of the assertion dead code under the rule — removal can change behaviour in builds where assertions are enabled or when an invariant is violated. Only if it can be proven (for all possible executions of the project) that the checked condition is always true and that the assert has no observable side‑effects would the operation be dead; that proof is not shown here. Consequently the blanket claim that these LFS_ASSERTs violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is incorrect.
